docs.lead_paragraph: The stock of Sonic Innovations Inc., a maker of hearing aids, fell 38 percent yesterday after the company lowered its second-quarter earnings forecast, citing cutbacks in health care benefits in Germany. The company, which is based in Salt Lake City, said on Monday that Germany cut reimbursements for hearing aids by about 8 percent, and a co-payment was instituted for specialist doctor visits, including visits to physicians who fit hearing aids. The company said it did not expect German sales to return to first-quarter levels for the rest of the year. Sonic said it now expected second-quarter earnings of 2 cents to 4 cents a share on sales of $24 million to $25 million, below the earnings of 7 cents a share and revenue of $27.1 million expected by Wall Street analysts. Its shares fell $3.51, to $5.66 a share.

headline.main: SONIC INNOVATIONS SHARES FALL ON REDUCED OUTLOOK

docs.abstract: Stock of Sonic Innovations Inc, maker of hearing aids, drops 38 percent after company lowers its second-quarter earnings forecast, citing cutbacks in health care benefits in Germany (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A surge in gasoline prices lifted the Consumer Price Index by 0.6 percent in May, the largest monthly increase in three and a half years, the government reported yesterday. Food prices also jumped while the prices of many other items went up by enough to suggest that the inflation rate will continue to climb gradually. The financial markets, however, viewed the latest inflation numbers as nonthreatening and evidence that the Federal Reserve will stick to its plan of ''measured'' increases in interest rates.

headline.main: Gas Prices Lead Gradual Rise in Inflation

docs.abstract: Bureau of Labor Statistics reports surge in gasoline prices lifted Consumer Price Index by 0.6 percent in May, largest increase in three and a half years; so-called core inflation rate rose 0.2 percent; core rate has risen 1.7 percent over 12-month period ended in May; food prices rose 0.9 percent, up from 0.2 percent in April, because of sharp increases in meat and dairy prices; big factor was 33 percent increase in government's support price paid to farmers for gallon of milk, which is passed on to consumers; housing costs rose 0.4 percent in May after same increase in April; medical costs rose 0.4 percent in May and April and 4.6 percent over last 12 months; Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan says Fed is likely to raise feeral funds rate slowly, until it is close to what it considers neutral level for healthy economy with mild inflation, testimony before Senate Banking Committee; graph; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal-Mogul Corporation said on Monday that it would seek to close an auto bearings plant in southwestern Michigan after workers rejected a contract that would have cut their wages, vacations and health benefits. The company has been seeking $5.35 million to $5.5 million in wage and benefit concessions in exchange for keeping the plant open and preserving its 310 jobs.
docs.abstract: Federal-Mogul Corp will seek to close auto bearings plant in southwestern Michigan after workers reject contract that would have cut their wages, vacations and health benefits (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: After years without enough money to make capital improvements, hospitals say they want to go on a spending spree -- building surgery centers, renovating operating rooms, buying the latest medical equipment and even putting in badly needed new computer systems. The big question is how long this can last. Hospital executives plan to increase their capital spending by an average of 14 percent a year for the next five years, according to a recent survey.

headline.main: Hospitals, Eager to Build, May Find Funds Scarcer

docs.abstract: American hospitals will have hard time raising money for ambitious plans to build surgery centers, renovate operating rooms, buy latest medical equipment and put in badly needed new computer systems; expected rise in interest rates will make borrowing much more expensive, because hospitals, typically run as nonprofit organizations, frequently raise money by issuing tax-exmept bonds; hospitals that plan to finance projects with cash from operations could see future revenue squeezed as private insurers balk at paying ever-higher prices for care and federal government looks for ways to cut budget; Temple University Health System chief financial officer, Robert Lux, who is overseeing construction of Temple's ambulatory care center, says raising money for such projects through donations is also becoming harder; graph; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The California Public Employees' Retirement System, or Calpers, said yesterday that it would fight the proposed acquisition of WellPoint Health Networks by Anthem, because it believed that WellPoint executives would receive excessive severance payments. If completed, the acquisition would create the biggest health insurance company in the nation, with 27 million members. Calpers said it would vote no on the proxy vote, scheduled for June 28. Calpers' investment committee said it would also urge other shareholders to oppose the merger and would ask Institutional Shareholder Services to reconsider its support for the merger. Additionally, the committee said it would seek a public hearing with California's managed health care committee to limit the executive compensation within the merger contract. WellPoint is the parent company of Blue Cross of California, which provides health care services to Calpers.

headline.main: Calpers Opposes Anthem Takeover of WellPoint

docs.abstract: California Public Employees' Retirement System will fight proposed acquisition of WellPoint Health Networks by Anthem because it believes WellPoint executives will receive excessive severance payments (S)
